overview_of_class:
Religion is all around us. Whether we do or do not personally identify as religious, the impact of religious customs, ideas, motivations, expressions, objects, spaces, and so on is pervasive in our lives - from the most mundane everyday aspects to the biggest and most burning issues of politics, healthcare, race relations, gender equality, and climate change. One cannot be an informed citizen of the world without a rich and profound understanding of religion and its place in human society.

This course sets out to develop a deeper and broader understanding of religion as a human phenomenon, by focusing on three interrelated questions: What, How, and Why. In the "what" part we will ask what is a religion, what different religions have in common, what are some of the key traits of religious spaces, times, experiences, and experience, and also what are different forms of non-religion (secularism, atheism, etc.). In the "how" part we will explore different approaches to the study of religion: psychological, sociological, philosophical, etc. And in the "why" part we will examine the impact of religion on various contemporary issues: gender, politics, medicine, economics, and more.

Students will read primary religious texts, works of fiction (literature and TV/film), and academic articles; write short response papers that analyze and evaluate different approaches to the study of religion; write critical essays that utilize the terms, approaches, and perspectives studied in class toward independent analysis; engage in debates with diverse perspectives; and generally learn to consider religion in a multilayered, historically informed, and non-essentialzing way.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
1) Students will be able to critically utilize and discuss key concepts in the study of religion (such as belief, ritual, scripture, sacred, etc.) with awareness of historical, regional, communal, and individual diversity;
2) Analyze religious phenomena, ideas, and texts from a variety of perspectives and points of view;
3) Evaluate the strengths and weaknesses of different scholarly works (articles, books, etc.) on religious communities, traditions, and practices;
4) Reflect critically on representations of religion in media, popular culture, and various areas of knowledge;
5) Communicate ideas and analyses clearly and coherently through written assignments and through class discussions;
6) Collaborate with peers in respectful, informed, and productive conversations.
